thread.title: World's biggest plane to become regular visitor to UK | Daily Mail Online
thread.title_full: World's biggest plane to become regular visitor to UK | Daily Mail Online

author: Rory Tingle For Mailonline
title: World's biggest plane to become regular visitor to UK | Daily Mail Online
text:
Share this article Share The six-engine, 600 tonne aircraft was initially built to transport the Soviet space shuttle 'the Buran' in the late 1980s Michael Goodisman, from the Antonov Airlines UK office, told Graeme Paton of The Times: 'This is all about Antonov’s desire to engage with the West . . . and develop a closer relationship with the UK.' The company opened their base in Stansted last month, and mainly use a fleet of seven An-124s, which have four engines rather than eight, for its regular operations. Its sole An-225 has made 11 trips to the UK using airports including RAF Brize Norton, Manchester, Prestwick and Doncaster-Sheffield. The 600 tonne An-225 was once was used to transport a Soviet space shuttle on its roof. It was designed and built in Ukraine in the 1980s and is used to move heavy cargoes, a recent example of which was an enormous 117 tonne power generator. Michael Goodisman, from the Antonov Airlines UK office, said: 'This is all about Antonov’s desire to engage with the West . . . and develop a closer relationship with the UK' Capable of carrying the the equivalent of ten British battle tanks, the aircraft has previously transported a 117 tonne electric generator (pictured) to a mining company in Perth The company opened their base in Stansted last month, and mainly use a fleet of seven An-124s, which have four engines rather than eight, for its regular operations The electric generator was picked up from the Czech Republic last May and delivered to an aluminium-ore mining company in western Australia, where it will be used to power large drills and excavating machinery. Measuring in at 84 yards long and with a wingspan of 88 yard - almost twice the width of a traditional football field - the plane has acted as a commercial transporter of oversized payloads for over two decades. Without a load, the colossal Antonov An-225 Mriya (Ukrainian for 'dream') can fly for up to 18 hours without stopping to refuel. The unloading phase of the generator on board could take up to 10 hours. Its sole An-225 has made 11 trips to the UK using airports including RAF Brize Norton, Manchester, Prestwick and Doncaster-Sheffield Without a load, the colossal aircraft can fly for up to 18 hours without stopping to refuel The Antonov An-225 has twice the wing area of a Boeing 747, and its wingspan spreads the width of nearly two football fields Read more: Share or comment on this article 
Well, let's hope that's as well built as the Americ...
